Review Text: This lake is actually a reservoir created under the reign of King Parakrambahu. His reign was the height of Polonnaruwa, a time of great construction. He is credited with a pathetic phrase: "No rain drop can sail into the ocean without serving the people." Logically, the reservoir was named after him - "the Parakram Sea." In the 12th century, the reservoir had a huge area of 2,500 hectares and was not quite in the same place as it is today.
Beautiful and serene site. Kept very clean. Lovely breeze. Even more beautiful when one learns all about its history. Definitely worth a visit.
As you drive around it, you realize how huge it is. Beautiful. Also, a good place for people watching.

The reservoir was built by King Parakramabahu 1 in an attempt to alleviate water shortages during the dry seasons. There were 5 reservoirs to ease the pressure on the main dam. Thopa Vewa was constructed in 386AD and the King had the other  four reservoirs built and the system expanded with many smaller reservoirs to built to feed the five primary and take away any excess water. It was a complex ancient technology that worked until reconstructed in the 19th century when a structural design error altered the water flows. As a result there are now two lakes the largest consisting of Thopa Vewa, Eramudu Vewa and Dumbuthula Vewa and the smaller Kalahagala Vewa and Bhu Vewa. A very scenic area and we had the good fortune to see a small herd of seven elephants nearby.

DescriptionParakrama Samudra is a shallow reservoir, consisting of five separate reservoirs connected by narrow channels in Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka. The northernmost reservoir is the oldest and referred to as Topa wewa built around 386 AD For more info - www.facebook.com/reisesl

giant water tank in polonnaruwa,fresh breeze,very interesting,high technological knowledge based irrigation system is there,evening boat fishermen are eye catching with sunset view,last week i visited the area,very interesting place at evening and early morning,

me and my family visited the place,we had a driver,guide,and the place was so amazing,fresh breeze,blue water,very attractive,giant water tank like a sea guide explained us that there was a huge irrigation system,and nice history we spent nearly 2 hrs there,and we saw sun set view,great!!
A very big lake, popularly known as 'samudra' meaning 'sea' is worth visiting. It is providing water for irrigation, power generation, navigation, fishing and lot more activities.

The road leading to Polonnaruwa, while it approached the town, is lined by a large water body, which appears quiet soothing and beautiful. The lake is manmade, many centuries ago and the government has taken over its up keep in the recent years. The water body supports many species of birds and animals as well there is a lot of greenery on its banks. The nearest banks are walking distance from the Museum and from where bicycles can be hired for sightseeing. It forms the first spot of a guided tour.
It's really huge river situated in polonnaruwa.very beautiful Sun rising and Sunset. I hired to bicycle to there.It's was perfect remembered to me

This dammed lake borders the town and there a few places to see it from close to the ruins, in particular if you ride south from the museum towards the southern group of ruins.  Many hotels are alongside the lake and these can be very pleasant - quiet, lots of wildlife and good sunset views.

Great place for a serene drive with friends. Great scenic beauty with lake on one side and tropical fields on others. Difficult to find a place to stop you car and enjoy, since its a single lane road. Yet a must visit
This is a man made tank by the king to irrigate the agricultural lands.Later on renovated by the government.A good place to visit with a local .

Parakrama Smudraya-Sea of Parakrama is one of the greatest milestone of Sri It is the Sri Lankan irrigation history. Parakramabahu Great ( 1164-1196 AD) built this reservoir by connecting five nearby lakes during Polonnaruwa era. Latest renovation happened at latter part of colonial era under the guidance of Sir D.S.Senanayaka. There are many things to visit around Parakrama Samudraya. We had an opportunity to have a boat ride at Parakrama Samudraya by fishing boats. It was a half a day journey without life jackets. Better visit this place having the background history knowledge. A very large man made water body to hold & retain water for agricultural purposes built by the ancient Kings. Parakrama Samudra (or King Parakrama's sea or the Sea of King Parakrama) is a shallow reservoir, consisting of three separate reservoirs connected by narrow channels in Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka. There are plenty of wonderful sights in Sri Lanka relating to their heritage and the Buddhist faith. It is peaceful and very well preserved. You can drive all along the dam for so many miles up to the other end of the lake. Locals call it Parakrama Samudraya meaning "Parakarama Sea" indicating it is quite large compared to thousands other man-made Lakes (Locals call it Weva) in and around Agricultural areas in the country. The same King is famous for saying " I will not allow any bit of Water fallen from the Sky (Rain) to be drained out to Sea without utilising for my public"  Irrigation system which is still used today, yes it is a tank, but you would not know it. It circles the city and was used as a defensive border against intruders many years ago. It was an amazing experience to cross different parts of the lake by fishery boats. There are some paid boat tours organized by surrounding hotels at Parakrama Samudraya. You will definitely feel a Sea like atmosphere when tank is fully filled and wonder how such large dams are built during those times (11th Century) without heavy Machinery or technology. Look other side and you will be more surprised to see astonishing Brick and Stone work in ancient Polonnaruwa City thought to be built around same time also using soil dredged to make the lake. It is a great experience in a morning. We drove towards the Angamadilla village and parked in many places to observe the scenic views of the lake. You may even ride in a bike. For a long ride, morning 6-7am is recommended. But for eve, you shall only ride along the main dam as elephants are coming to the rural end. Paddling a local’s made ORUWA in Parakrama Samudraya was a delightful experience we had. This is a rare chance we had.  Sitting and watching in-front of the lake at sunset is really wonderful. Do not use liquor since the police are always watch nearby.

Latest renovation happened at latter part of colonial era under the guidance of Sir D.S.Senanayaka. There are many things to visit around Parakrama Samudraya. I had an opputunity to have a boat ride at Parakrama Samudraya by fishing boats. It was a half a day journey without life jackets. It was an amazing experience to cross different parts of the lake by fishery boats. There are some paid boat tours organized by surrounding hotels at Parakrama Samudraya.

The same King is famous for saying " I will not allow any bit of Water fallen from the Sky (Rain) to be drained out to Sea without utilising for my public " You will definitely feel a Sea like atmosphere when tank is fully filled and wonder how such large dams are built during those times (11th Century ) without heavy Machinery or technology.  Look other side and you will be more surprised to see astonishing Brick and Stone work in ancient Polonnaruwa City thought to be build around same time also using soil dredged to make the lake.

A very large man made water body to hold & retain water for agricultural purposes built by the ancient Kings.
Parakrama Samudra (or King Parakrama's sea or the Sea of King Parakrama) is a shallow reservoir, consisting of three separate reservoirs connected by narrow channels in Polonnaruwa, Sri Lanka.

There are plenty of wonderful sights in Sri Lanka relating to their heritage and the Buddhist faith. This whole area is worth a visit but do it gently and let your imagination run away with you. It is peaceful and very well preserved. Worthy of a few hours.
Paddling a local’s made ORUWA in Parakrama Samudraya was a delightful experience we had. This is a rare chance we had. Thank’s to Sudu Aralia Hotel.

The 'tank' at Polonnaruwa is huge and beautiful - it's hard to believe that it's a man-made lake. Our guidebook indicates that it goes under the name of 'Topa Wewa (Parakrama Samudra)'. We cycled past it late in the afternoon on our way from the main archeological sites in the north to Potgul Vihara in the south. Although we didn't come across any tourist facilities on the quiet Lake Road, in our opinion, it's still worth taking a few minutes to relax and admire the views.
Irrigation system which is still used today, yes it is a tank, but you would not know it. It circles the city and was used as a defensive border against intruders many years ago.
Sitting and watching infront of the lake at sunset is really wonderful.Do not use liquor since the police are always watching nearby.

Dating 8-12th century AD this giant water tank consists of 3 tanks combined together to make it one giant tank, the bund around the tank spans 14kms, whilst feeding the irrigation system around Polonnaruwa and surrounding areas it feeds water in to smaller tanks around and helps the region to be amongst the top areas of paddy cultivation, don't miss out to see the Parakrama statue, Nissanka Lathaa Mandapaya which are related ancient ruins in the vicinity, No public WC close by, if you are visiting only this site you don't have to buy any entry tickets well for now! Enjoy

Parākramabāhu I also known as 'Maha Parākramabāhu' was king of Sri Lanka from 1153 to 1186. Samudra Parakrama alos known as Parakrama Samudra is the largest irrigation tank of king Parakramabahu I. Its 5,600 acres of  water irrigated an estimated 18,200 acres of paddy land during that time. Samudra in sinhala means sea hence Parakrama Samudra means King Parakrama's sea.

This has to qualify as one of the most far seeing constructions in Asia. The king (seen to be almost as a god by his people) built this lake/reservoir as part of a complex and sophisticated irrigation system which led to great prosperity for his country. Perhaps it has ultimately helped to make Sri Lanka so different to its much larger neighbour even today?
